Mass. R. Civ. P. 10(a).proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction and venue is proper in Hampden County Superior Court under the Massachusetts venue statutes and rules because the claims arose in this county and the defendant resides here.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 8(a).proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction and venue is proper in Hampden County Superior Court under the Massachusetts venue statutes and rules because the claims arose in this county and the defendant resides here.

Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. (6 Cush.) 292.proposition: At all times material, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the storage, securing, and maintenance of his property (including the ladder), so as not to create an unreasonable risk of harm to neighbors’ persons or property.
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. (6 Cush.) 292.support_reasoning: The case addresses a defendant’s duty to exercise ordinary (reasonable) care when engaging in affirmative conduct that unintentionally injures another, but it does so in the context of an assault-and-battery/trespass action involving an active intervention (separating fighting dogs), not passive storage or maintenance of property. It articulates a general negligence standard and burden of proof, not a specific duty concerning storage, securing, or maintenance of property so as not to create risks to neighbors. Thus it is too contextually different to be proper authority for the specific duty described in the proposition.
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. (6 Cush.) 292.relevant_excerpt: “In using this term, ordinary care, it may be proper to state, that what constitutes ordinary care will vary with the circumstances of cases. In general, it means that kind and degree of care, which prudent and cautious men would use, such as is required by the exigency of the case, and such as is necessary to guard against probable danger. … If… the defendant was doing a lawful act, and unintentionally hit and hurt the plaintiff, then unless it also appears… that the defendant is chargeable with some fault, negligence, carelessness, or want of prudence, the plaintiff… is not entitled to recover.”

Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by, among other things, negligently leaving a tall extension ladder unsecured and leaning against a shared fence in an area accessible to wind gusts; failing to tie down, move, or otherwise secure the ladder despite prior warnings and requests by Plaintiff; and otherwise failing to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions were the direct and proximate cause of the ladder falling and striking Plaintiff’s vehicle on or about March 15, 2023, thereby causing the property damage alleged herein.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf does not support the asserted proposition that a defendant’s negligent acts were the direct and proximate cause of a specific later accident (the ladder falling on plaintiff’s vehicle in 2023). Instead, Cardozo’s opinion holds that there was no actionable negligence toward the plaintiff because she was outside the range of reasonably foreseeable risk, and expressly states that questions of proximate cause are “foreign to the case” once no duty is found. The case is frequently cited to limit liability based on duty and foreseeability, not to establish that negligence was the direct and proximate cause of particular property damage.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us. The question of liability is always anterior to the question of the measure of the consequences that go with liability. If there is no tort to be redressed, there is no occasion to consider what damage might be recovered if there were a finding of a tort… Here, by concession, there was nothing in the situation to suggest to the most cautious mind that the parcel wrapped in newspaper would spread wreckage through the station.”
